initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories:
The US Embassy in Moscow is working closely with Russian authorities to ensure that Sgt Black receives fair treatment and due process in accordance with Russian law. The US Army and the Department of State are providing all possible assistance to Sgt Black and his family during this time.

Meanwhile, the US continues to urge Russia to respect the rights of all detainees, including American citizens, and to provide them with access to consular services. The US remains committed to protecting the safety and well-being of all American citizens abroad.

The US government also reiterates its call for the release of Evan Gershkovich and Paul Whelan, who have been wrongfully detained in Russia on baseless charges. We will not rest until they are reunited with their families.

The US Army reminds all service members of the importance of following regulations and protocols regarding international travel, especially when traveling to countries with potential security concerns. We stand by our soldiers and will support them through any challenges they may face, both at home and abroad.

The US Embassy in Moscow will continue to advocate for Sgt Black's rights and work towards a swift resolution in his case. We remain in close contact with Russian authorities and are exploring all avenues for his release. In the meantime, we will provide Sgt Black and his family with all necessary resources and support.

At the same time, we will not waver in our demand for the immediate release of Evan Gershkovich and Paul Whelan. Their detention is a violation of international law and a breach of diplomatic norms. We will not rest until they are reunited with their families and returned to the United States.

We urge all American citizens, especially those traveling abroad, to remain vigilant and aware of their surroundings. Follow all local laws and regulations, and stay in touch with the US Embassy or Consulate in your area. We will continue to do everything in our power to protect and support you, no matter where you are in the world.

We are deeply concerned about the welfare and safety of Sgt Black, Evan Gershkovich, and Paul Whelan. Their unjust detentions are a priority for us, and we will not relent in our efforts to secure their release. We will keep the families informed of any developments and continue to work with Russian authorities to find a peaceful resolution.

In the meantime, we strongly advise all U.S. citizens to exercise caution and maintain situational awareness while traveling abroad. Keep emergency contact information on hand and stay informed about local conditions and any potential risks. If you encounter any issues or need assistance, do not hesitate to contact the U.S. Embassy or Consulate in your area. We will do everything in our power to help you navigate any challenges you may face.

We understand that these uncertain times may cause anxiety and concern for travelers. Rest assured that the safety and security of U.S. citizens is our top priority. In addition to staying informed and taking necessary precautions, we encourage you to enroll in the Smart Traveler Enrollment Program (STEP). This free service allows us to keep you updated with important information and contact you in case of emergencies. Together, we can work to ensure a safe and successful journey for all U.S. citizens abroad.

We are continuously monitoring the situation and will provide you with regular updates through STEP. If you need assistance, please don't hesitate to contact us at the nearest U.S. embassy or consulate. We are here to help you navigate any challenges you may face during your travels. Stay safe and smart, and know that we are with you every step of the way.

In the meantime, we strongly encourage you to review the travel advisories and safety tips on our website and app. Keep your emergency contact information up-to-date and consider enrolling in the Smart Traveler Enrollment Program (STEP) if you haven't already. Remember, being informed and prepared can go a long way in ensuring a safe and enjoyable trip. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or concerns. We're here to help.

Additionally, make sure to check with your healthcare provider for any necessary vaccinations or medications for your destination. Familiarize yourself with local customs and laws, and be aware of any potential scams or safety concerns at your destination. Stay informed about any ongoing situations or incidents that may affect your travel plans. We wish you a safe and memorable trip!
